Comments_List: I learned about important models in empirical IO: BLP-style differentiated goods markets, auctions, single- and multi-agent dynamic discrete choice problems, and production function estimation.  I also learned how to practically estimate basic forms of these structural models in Matlab.
Demand estimation, Auction and Dynamic Models.
Building dynamic models, estimation, and review of literature.
I learned a lot of good quantitative methods.

Knowledge of various literatures in industrial organization (IO).
Skills: Reading papers in IO. Estimating structural IO models.

I thought that the problem sets were an important and valuable part of the course.  The one-page summaries required by Phil Haile provided a good accountability mechanism to ensure I at least understood the broad strokes of the paper before attending the relevant class.  I also enjoyed Phil's somewhat philosophical lecture on modeling and estimation.  Both instructors gave good lectures.  

It would have been nice to have feedback on the problem sets.  I don't expect it's feasible for the professors to check our code for errors and bugs, but I do believe that they have knowledge vastly surpassing mine when it comes to writing code and especially solving the practical issues that arise in these models, and I would have liked for them to have directly imparted more of that knowledge (as, for example, Cormac O'Dea does in his class).   In the absence of a posted example solution code, some high-level comments about correcting common mistakes and following best practices for efficient coding might be useful.
Great course. Well structured. Challenging but well-defined problem sets. Should have got feedback on psets.

Strengths: rigorous
Weakness: more of a personal thing, but I didn't find auctions that interesting
Strengths: Quality of instruction. Well-designed problem sets.
I would strongly recommend this class to any student who wanted to understand workhorse Empirical IO models and/or the estimation of structural models.
Yes. Psets are really useful. Good lectures. Well organized.

I took this class because I initially was considering IO as one of my fields. I decided not to take the field exam because I don't see myself doing IO research, but I'm really glad I took the class. It offers good methods training and exposure to material that every economist should know, like discrete choice models and production function estimation.
Yale has a great group of IO researchers. It was great to take this course.
